SC Investigates Discipline,
Rejects Campaign Checks
In its two principle items of
business last week the Student
Council took up the matter its
jurisdiction in student disciplinary problems and the question
of regulating campaign expenditures in student elections.
Last week one or possibly two
Hopkins students were involved
in incidents on the Towson State
Campus. One rowdy student had
to be thrown out of a dance,
the other—if not the same—was
caught with liquor in his car.
Dean Morrill asked the Council
whether it wanted to have some
say in the disciplinary action
taken.
Jurisdiction Questioned
To the Council it was a problem of jurisdiction. Disciplinary
matters, particularly where they
do not greatly reflect on the
school's reputation, have not, as
a matter of policy, been submitted to the Council before. The
Council was consequently somewhat perplexed as to how to
handle the matter.
In the end the Council both

resolved to take this particular
case into consideration and also
appointed a committee, headed
by John Sanborn, to investigate
what the Council should do when
matters of discipline reflect on
Hopkins' image.
Campaign Funds
Representative Bob Feibel proposed that student campaign expenditures be limited. The present policy of no policy seemed
to be unfair to some candidates
who could not afford to spend
as much on publicity as their
fellow contenders.
Several Councilmen thought
that such regulation was difficult
to supervise and unnecessary.
One Freshman chastised the
Council for far too hasty and unreasoned entry into this field.
The proposal was subsequently
defeated.
It was also announced that the
YMCA would like a student
opinion poll concerning who
should be invited for the Big
Weekend Concert next Spring.

IFC Resolutions
In Its weekly meeting last
Week, the Interfraternity Council
passcd three resolutions concerning its position on the fraternitydiscrimination issue.
The IFC, representing its fourteen member fraternities, placed
itself against discrimination by a
fraternity on the basis of race,
creed, or color.
It was further resolved that
the IFC and its member fraternities object to the suggesting,

seeking, or forcing of any administrative action on a question
concerning only those people
connected with fraternities.
Finally, it was resolved by the
fraternities, through the IFC, to
"refuse to acknowledge or participate in the recent public
opinion poll as it requests an
emotional response rather than
a rational conclusion, which can
only come from those either in
or intimately connected with the
fraternity system."

BY GREG ALTSCHUH
Dr. Martin Luther King, winner of the 1964 Nobel
Peace Prize,
will speak in Shriver Hall at 5 P.M. Monday,
January 11.
The Hopkins chapter of Phi Beta Kappa and the
Committee
on Special Events are co-sponsoring the lecture. Dr. Carl
Swanson
is President of P.B.K.
Dr. King has been asked to discuss "The Limits of
Freedom."
Youngest Winner
Dr. King, 35, is the youngest winner ever of a Nobel peace
prize, which includes a stipend of $54.000. Deeply moved by this
honor, he stated that every penny of the prize money would be
given to the civil rights movement. To Dr. King the prise is a
sign that world opinion is on the side of those struggling for
freedom and dignity.
The prize is awarded each year to the person "who has done
the most for the furtherance of brotherhood among men and to
the abolishment or reduction of standing armies and for the exProfessor Chandler received tension of these purposes."
an A.B. degree from Harvard in
Twelfth American
Dr. King is the twelfth American and the third Negro to be
1940. After five years of warawarded a peace prize. He will receive it from the Norwegian
parliament in Oslo on December 10.
He earned his A.B. at Morehouse College in 1948 and received
his Ph.D. at Boston University in systematic theology in 1955. Dr.
King became famous in the trm boycott in Montgomery, Alabama
in December of 1955.
President of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and
pastor of Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery, Dr. King
is the author of Stride Toward Freedom (1958) and has recently
published Why We Can't Wait.
Now that the civil rights act has become law. Dr. King is
considering new ways to apply non-violence to secure reforms for
American Negroes.

Campus Notes
Yetta Returns
Yetta Bronstein, the only
woman candidate for President
of the United States, will speak
again to the Hopkins community
on WJHU Monday night at 7:00.
The speech will be a tape of
the Yetta rally held last spring.
Mrs. Bronstein, who is the wife
of a Brooklyn cabdriver, was invited to the campus last year
through the vigorous efforts of
the News-Letter and the radio
station. Her rally proved to be
one of the most exciting events
history, and
Homewood
in
through popular demand, JWHU
is replaying the tape of that historic occasion.
Yetta, a candidate of The Best
Party, is running on a platform
that includes better government,
floridation, national sex education, stronger government, lowering of the voting age to 18,
and national bingo. One of her
most enthusiastically received
proposals is to raise postal
revenues by placing Jayne Mansfield on a postage stamp. Alan
Abel, national campaign manager for Mrs. Bronstein, believes
dissatisfaction with both candidates will sweep her into office on election day, and James
Freedman and Caleb Deschanel,
heads of the local chapter of
Young Yettas, are working toward promoting her candidacy
at Hopkins.

if it were rising, for as it becomes more and more essential
unto itself, it shall correspondingly appear to diminish in
magnitude, until finally the
Great Pumpkin shall be seen to
become one with All, which it is,
and this transformation shall
appear as the rapid ascension
of the orange sphere into the
boundless volume that is populated by the fixed and motionless stars. And thus it has been
written that that day of days
shall close, and that we shall
wonder over these mysteries of
the Great Pumpkin.
"One more thing remains to
be acocunted for, since not all
pumpkins rose up into the Great
Pumpkin. And it was for these
pumpkins that the huge noise
of the portals brought the meaningless terror, brought the anxiety of non-relation, brought
the fear of a self that has been
stripped of its temporal and material relations. For these were
the pumpkins whose essential
nature was unreceptive to the
Force; these were the pumpkins
who when released from their
weight had no essence save existence, and existence alone
feels not the Force. For lo, it
was written that every pumpkin
has but one summer to live,
and thus but one summer to
become, for the existence was

given, as to a rock, but only
pumpkins were given the opportunity to become more than
existence, and this becoming is
a great mystery in every way,
but it is enough for a pumpkin
to know this, as no pumpkin
can understand, nor can it hope
to understand. A pumpkin is able
to act on and create essential
nature, and if it does this in any
way then that essence shall be
receptive to the Force. But the
pumpkins left behind are those
who never developed an essential nature other than the given
existence—these are the pumpkins who sought to exist only in
relation to other existing objects
—never were they essential within themselves. And it was written that these pumpkins would
see the day when their existential relations would be stripped
away, and they must exhibit
essential characteristics wholly
dependent on themselves, and
these pumpkins knew, as it was

clearly written, that there was
but one brief summer for this
to be done. The pumpkins that
remain on the earth are now
without weight, and hence they
have lost all relation to other
pumpkins. Now they have no opportunity to become, and, unrelated to all other entities, they
will gradually diffuse and exist
alone. And it is a peculiarity of
pumpkins that if they have no
apparent essential nature save
existence this will be a great
terror to them, and entail a certain unending anxiety and anguish. This is the fate of the
pumpkins left behind after the
departure of the Great Pumpkin—as to why these pumpkins
neglected to become during their
brief summer is a problem which
will not be dealt with at present,
suffice it to know that this neglect is related, in no small way,
to the actions of an entity which
is commonly referred to as the
Pump Greatkin.

The question of the legitimacy of outside interference in the internal matters of a private social organization has been a potent argument against Administrative action to see that discrimination is removed
from the Hopkins campus. Arguments of passion, on
both sides of the general controversy have obscured
this important question, the answer to which resides in
some facts as yet unregarded.
Certainly a fraternity is a private organization, but
has other facets to its condition which remove it from
the sort of public-private distinctions which apply in
civil rights legislation. This private organization, though
k determines its own membership from within, does
not function, as a group of members, in complete separation from the public realm at the Homewood. It
functions also as a part of the Hopkins community
when it joins in support of activities here, and when it
performs any acts with other fraternities. It participates
in a University sanctioned B.I.A. program, and an Interfraternity Council.
Much more important, however, is the fact that any
fraternity exists here only through the permission of the
Administration. Administrative permission must be obtained prior to establishment of a chapter. Thereafter,

The Great Pumpkin Explained
By PETER NELSON
"The Great Pumpkin is a
sphere rotating on its axis—it
moves not from place to place,
which would indicate its dependence on relation to other
bodies, but moves continually in

Two For America
Candidacy status for the
American Presidency appears
this year to be more widely
available than it has ever been.
It used to be that everybody
and h4 brother would get his
two bits into the race, verbally
at least. This is evidently still,
quite literally, true. But more
recently, this same everyman
and his brother are going one
step farther and pushing for
the office itself.
The Hopkins political arena
Is sporting two of the front-line
contenders for the presidency.
Marvin Kitman and Mrs. Yetta
Bronstein, while not among the
dateline personalities of the nation, have decorated Gilman
Hall in their campaign pursuit.
Office Calls
They have surprisingly parallel
campaigns, seeing issues probably from the same level of likelihood. Kitman, the editor of the
humor magazine, Monicle, is
recognized immediately by political insiders as the writer who
renounced his craft ("I'd rather
be President than write.") to
enter the race: a proposition not
SO unattractive to many of us.
Yetta, on the other hand, is
renouncing and sacrificing nothing for the office. On the contrary, she is bringing herself, a
citizen, over 35 and past den

aspirations rising in the underdeveloped nations and with her

even if he is roundly defeated,
Johnson's victory will not show
anything but the rejection of an
Untenable alternative from a

be larger than we are willing to
believe.

SC Investigates Discipline,
Rejects Campaign Checks
In its two principle items of
business last week the Student
Council took up the matter its
jurisdiction in student disciplinary problems and the question
of regulating campaign expenditures in student elections.
Last week one or possibly two
Hopkins students were involved
in incidents on the Towson State
Campus. One rowdy student had
to be thrown out of a dance,
the other—if not the same—was
caught with liquor in his car.
Dean Morrill asked the Council
whether it wanted to have some
say in the disciplinary action
taken.
Jurisdiction Questioned
To the Council it was a problem of jurisdiction. Disciplinary
matters, particularly where they
do not greatly reflect on the
school's reputation, have not, as
a matter of policy, been submitted to the Council before. The
Council was consequently somewhat perplexed as to how to
handle the matter.
In the end the Council both

resolved to take this particular
case into consideration and also
appointed a committee, headed
by John Sanborn, to investigate
what the Council should do when
matters of discipline reflect on
Hopkins' image.
Campaign Funds
Representative Bob Feibel proposed that student campaign expenditures be limited. The present policy of no policy seemed
to be unfair to some candidates
who could not afford to spend
as much on publicity as their
fellow contenders.
Several Councilmen thought
that such regulation was difficult
to supervise and unnecessary.
One Freshman chastised the
Council for far too hasty and unreasoned entry into this field.
The proposal was subsequently
defeated.
It was also announced that the
YMCA would like a student
opinion poll concerning who
should be invited for the Big
Weekend Concert next Spring.

IFC Resolutions
In Its weekly meeting last
Week, the Interfraternity Council
passcd three resolutions concerning its position on the fraternitydiscrimination issue.
The IFC, representing its fourteen member fraternities, placed
itself against discrimination by a
fraternity on the basis of race,
creed, or color.
It was further resolved that
the IFC and its member fraternities object to the suggesting,

seeking, or forcing of any administrative action on a question
concerning only those people
connected with fraternities.
Finally, it was resolved by the
fraternities, through the IFC, to
"refuse to acknowledge or participate in the recent public
opinion poll as it requests an
emotional response rather than
a rational conclusion, which can
only come from those either in
or intimately connected with the
fraternity system."

BY GREG ALTSCHUH
Dr. Martin Luther King, winner of the 1964 Nobel
Peace Prize,
will speak in Shriver Hall at 5 P.M. Monday,
January 11.
The Hopkins chapter of Phi Beta Kappa and the
Committee
on Special Events are co-sponsoring the lecture. Dr. Carl
Swanson
is President of P.B.K.
Dr. King has been asked to discuss "The Limits of
Freedom."
Youngest Winner
Dr. King, 35, is the youngest winner ever of a Nobel peace
prize, which includes a stipend of $54.000. Deeply moved by this
honor, he stated that every penny of the prize money would be
given to the civil rights movement. To Dr. King the prise is a
sign that world opinion is on the side of those struggling for
freedom and dignity.
The prize is awarded each year to the person "who has done
the most for the furtherance of brotherhood among men and to
the abolishment or reduction of standing armies and for the exProfessor Chandler received tension of these purposes."
an A.B. degree from Harvard in
Twelfth American
Dr. King is the twelfth American and the third Negro to be
1940. After five years of warawarded a peace prize. He will receive it from the Norwegian
parliament in Oslo on December 10.
He earned his A.B. at Morehouse College in 1948 and received
his Ph.D. at Boston University in systematic theology in 1955. Dr.
King became famous in the trm boycott in Montgomery, Alabama
in December of 1955.
President of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and
pastor of Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery, Dr. King
is the author of Stride Toward Freedom (1958) and has recently
published Why We Can't Wait.
Now that the civil rights act has become law. Dr. King is
considering new ways to apply non-violence to secure reforms for
American Negroes.

Campus Notes
Yetta Returns
Yetta Bronstein, the only
woman candidate for President
of the United States, will speak
again to the Hopkins community
on WJHU Monday night at 7:00.
The speech will be a tape of
the Yetta rally held last spring.
Mrs. Bronstein, who is the wife
of a Brooklyn cabdriver, was invited to the campus last year
through the vigorous efforts of
the News-Letter and the radio
station. Her rally proved to be
one of the most exciting events
history, and
Homewood
in
through popular demand, JWHU
is replaying the tape of that historic occasion.
Yetta, a candidate of The Best
Party, is running on a platform
that includes better government,
floridation, national sex education, stronger government, lowering of the voting age to 18,
and national bingo. One of her
most enthusiastically received
proposals is to raise postal
revenues by placing Jayne Mansfield on a postage stamp. Alan
Abel, national campaign manager for Mrs. Bronstein, believes
dissatisfaction with both candidates will sweep her into office on election day, and James
Freedman and Caleb Deschanel,
heads of the local chapter of
Young Yettas, are working toward promoting her candidacy
at Hopkins.

The question of the legitimacy of outside interference in the internal matters of a private social organization has been a potent argument against Administrative action to see that discrimination is removed
from the Hopkins campus. Arguments of passion, on
both sides of the general controversy have obscured
this important question, the answer to which resides in
some facts as yet unregarded.
Certainly a fraternity is a private organization, but
has other facets to its condition which remove it from
the sort of public-private distinctions which apply in
civil rights legislation. This private organization, though
k determines its own membership from within, does
not function, as a group of members, in complete separation from the public realm at the Homewood. It
functions also as a part of the Hopkins community
when it joins in support of activities here, and when it
performs any acts with other fraternities. It participates
in a University sanctioned B.I.A. program, and an Interfraternity Council.
Much more important, however, is the fact that any
fraternity exists here only through the permission of the
Administration. Administrative permission must be obtained prior to establishment of a chapter. Thereafter,

The Great Pumpkin Explained
By PETER NELSON
"The Great Pumpkin is a
sphere rotating on its axis—it
moves not from place to place,
which would indicate its dependence on relation to other

in which the Great Pumpkin

Two For America
Candidacy status for the
American Presidency appears
this year to be more widely
available than it has ever been.
It used to be that everybody
and h4 brother would get his
two bits into the race, verbally
at least. This is evidently still,
quite literally, true. But more
recently, this same everyman
and his brother are going one
step farther and pushing for
the office itself.
The Hopkins political arena
Is sporting two of the front-line
contenders for the presidency.
Marvin Kitman and Mrs. Yetta
Bronstein, while not among the
dateline personalities of the nation, have decorated Gilman
Hall in their campaign pursuit.
Office Calls
They have surprisingly parallel
campaigns, seeing issues probably from the same level of likelihood. Kitman, the editor of the
humor magazine, Monicle, is
recognized immediately by political insiders as the writer who
renounced his craft ("I'd rather
be President than write.") to
enter the race: a proposition not
SO unattractive to many of us.
Yetta, on the other hand, is
renouncing and sacrificing nothing for the office. On the contrary, she is bringing herself, a
citizen, over 35 and past den

aspirations rising in the underdeveloped nations and with her

Johnson's victory will not show
